content.content: Hello, community. Here is the press release and letter from the (incubating) facilitator, for Maker Academy. We just finished an initial release of the product. Although 1) there are probably many small tweaks and bugs the team has not spotted and 2) the platform only accomplished 3% of the team’s product vision…we still think you will find it much more feature rich than other defi academies. Keep in mind, there are TONS of hidden features for users with higher permission levels, such as writing courses, articles, assessments, and even being able to submit edit requests on others’ content. If you would like a higher permission level, please DM me.  Press Release  Maker Academy Launch Announcement – Press Release Following an incubation period under MakerDAO’s Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling (SES), the Maker Academy officially launched its website on X. The Maker Academy is the latest Core Unit servicing the Maker Protocol. The main focus of the Maker Academy will be on educating people about the various elements of Maker (both Protocol and DAO). Over the last few months, the Maker Academy was incubating under the SES core unit. Core units are self-sufficient teams that manage specific verticals within Maker. These individual units are headed by one or more Governance Facilitators. The SES core unit is responsible for identifying various opportunities for ecosystem scaling. The Maker Academy was created to help scale up the DAO with educated users by providing a purely learning platform. “The Maker Academy is your one-stop guide to all things Maker. Whether you’re a new trying to understand how MakerDAO works or a contributor looking to help build, we’ve got everything you need to get started,” said Colby Anderson, the Facilitator and Head of the Maker Academy. “Currently, we have courses on the history of MakerDAO, the history of Maker Protocol, Maker Oracles, and Stablecoins. Stay tuned for more.” While the Maker Academy has a team that will create the baseline courses for its students, anyone who is knowledgeable about the ecosystem will be able to contribute.  About Maker Academy Maker Academy increases the proficiency of current/potential MakerDAO contributors and justifies the public adoption of MakerDAO’s products by facilitating the production of expert-curated content. The Maker Academy plans to educate all relevant audiences to MakerDAO ranging from end-users to laymen to contributors. Website: https://makerdao.academy/ Twitter: https://twitter.com/MakerAcademyCU  Letter From The Facilitator The Maker Academy has been a dream come true. It is so fulfilling to see something we have worked so hard on finally seeing the light of the day. I remember being instantly fascinated by MakerDAO and the possibilities of DeFi and a decentralized stablecoin. However, I saw a major problem as I began reading up on MakerDAO – there simply wasn’t any ideal starting point or a recommended pathway to get to the goal that I wanted. That seemed very odd to me. This is one of the world’s most important and game-changing protocols, yet why do I have to go to third-party sites to learn more about its technology? The worst part is that, more often than not, these third-party sites contained false and outdated information. Not to mention, these sites don’t provide in-depth info and offer only the tip of the iceberg As I kept going in deeper, I realized that:  All the information available is very haphazard and unorganized. This is not exclusive to Maker, but that’s not an excuse. The information that is available on third-party sites is not exactly in-depth and they are outdated. Many sites haven’t even bothered updating their articles when DAI graduated from SAI to MCD! Any protocol that’s governed by a DAO requires its token holders and other users that are somewhat educated about its technology and potential. This is why it is exponentially more important for Maker to have a powerful knowledge base. The Maker community is extremely passionate and generous with their knowledge and research in the forums. Why not give them a platform where they can share their knowledge in a readable and organized format? MakerDAO has several verticals. However, there is no tailored route of education for specific goals.  This was when I had the idea of a Maker Academy – a platform where not only can newbies gain in-depth knowledge about the various facets of MakerDAO and eventually contribute, but existing members can share their knowledge by becoming contributors. I shared the idea with the SES - Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling – core unit and one of its leads Wouter Kampmann, and he quickly realized its value. For almost a year, the Maker Academy has been incubating under the aegis of the SES. As we kept working on the academy, we were baffled by the content opportunities because of the sheer scope of MakerDAO. Think about it, we have the governance aspect, the protocol itself, the potential of DeFi, and the potential of stablecoins all wrapped in one! Along the way, I also realized the value of having a common design framework for contributing educational pieces to the Maker Community. We already have the MIP format for various improvement proposals, so why not have something similar for our community to share their knowledge? I believe we can bridge this gap with a solution like Maker Academy. We realized that we needed to grow the team and hire folks who understood the scope and importance of the work. Over the last few months, the team has worked tirelessly, and I am super happy and proud to launch what we have today. Colby Anderson. Facilitator – Maker Academy.
Wowzers, this is neat! Much need. TY and congrats to the Maker Academy team.
Education is a very valuable tool for adoption, delighted with what we are doing, and looking forward to expanding to other languages

sorry for being the party pooper but…  not sure how long you have been working on that, how big the team was and how much has been spent for it through the incubation program - so not really robust data so take it with a grain of salt: this feels like not a lot of bang for the buck this is yet another app that could just run decentralized, right? if we wanna keep that this comes with centralized expenses… why is this an app in the first place? we should not reinvent the wheel all the time, tools and services are out there to leverage i don’t want to create an account for anything on web3. login with metamask? sure - why not. but providing sensitive information for accessing information that should be publicly available is not crypto-native      colby:  I shared the idea with the SES - Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling – core unit and its facilitator Wouter Kampmann, and he quickly realized its value   btw… @wouter is not the facilitator…

Wanted to provide some extra context here as I believe it should be public info. Penn Blockchain was asked to create educational pieces for Maker Academy which in its current state and compensation (pro bono) we declined for now. The team seems pretty genuine and is an idea that definitely has some value. However in talks with the team, the extent of that value is another question. When it comes to costs, if I recall correctly, the project was allocated $600,000 DAI for a one year incubation, across what I remember to be 5 employees and 1 intern, equating to 100k-120k DAI per person. Additional MKR may or may not be on the table.

ultraschuppi:  why is this an app in the first place? we should not reinvent the wheel all the time, tools and services are out there to leverage   I have to agree. And what’s the point of a registration procedure? Why don’t just give the resources directly: wiki articles, videos, whatever. This just makes it harder to navigate, longer, harder to index, etc. What are opensource projects that have a structure like this `Maker Academy’?  Screenshot 2022-10-14 at 09.59.431882×874 50.1 KB  Why not use a combination of Wiki + StackExchange + Youtube (or others) + Khan Academy, etc without having “Maker Academy” in the middle, but rather on the side just transparently helping ‘students’ to interact with ‘experts’ ?

Juanbug:  However in talks with the team, the extent of that value is another question. When it comes to costs, if I recall correctly, the project was allocated $600,000 DAI for a one year incubation, across what I remember to be 5 employees and 1 intern, equating to 100k-120k DAI per person. Additional MKR may or may not be on the table.   uhm… can we get some solid numbers on that one please?

Could you elaborate on the quality control process? I’ve looked at the endgame documentation, and some fairly significant errors exist. I’d also caution you to consider how you present proposals that Maker Governance has not approved. Stating things like:  Maker plans on launching a simplified version of Synthetic ETH called “MATH. [sic]”  is untrue while still in the proposal phase. This may seem like semantics, but there is a risk of confusing people if they look to the Maker Academy site as a source of information. This could potentially harm Governance as people may assume proposals have already passed and not realise there is still time for them to comment or vote. Also, note it is no longer referred to as “MATH” in the proposal set.

There was an internal communication error which made this go out sooner than intended. Maker has a great need for more educational materials, and there is a lot of potential for a Maker Academy. The team has been working under challenging circumstances and is eager to engage with the community for more feedback. However, the product is not yet ready for a production release as many of you pointed out. We will leave the current version up as a staging environment instead but refrain from further public announcements for now. I’d kindly ask the mods to lock this forum thread for now. We will communicate again soon about next steps once we’ve reconvened internally. (By the way, not sure where the $600k is coming from, but that number has no basis in reality.)

This thread has been re-opened at the request of a Recognized Delegate who pointed out that this announcement was also made on Twitter and re-tweeted by the main Maker Twitter account. Given this level of publicity, it makes sense for this thread to remain open to comments.

A few clarifications:  The project was not allocated 600,000 DAI. There are currently 5 contributors, but this number was just reached recently. The project only had 2-3 contributors for quite some time. This project’s incubation process has been under 1 year still. Even if the project was allocated 600,000 DAI, an average contributor compensation could not be deduced from this number…as there are typically more budgeting categories than just compensation. For example, what if there were (although unrealistic) 100,000 DAI in legal and software licensing/contracting? During talks with Penn Blockchain, there was a budget cap that was mentioned, but this budget cap was a quick and very loose estimate for the future, when we would have more team members, more expenditures, a buffer, etc.

ultraschuppi:  this is yet another app that could just run decentralized, right? if we wanna keep that this comes with centralized expenses…   Not quite sure what you mean by “run decentralized”. Of course, like almost any software, it can be developed through unpaid open-source contributions.     ultraschuppi:  why is this an app in the first place? we should not reinvent the wheel all the time, tools and services are out there to leverage   The product vision for this site could not be effectively accomplished using multiple different applications. We plan to build an onboarding pipeline with this site—a place for users to get certifications for courses, etc and get recruited from the platform. The site you see now, is just a small, first-step in accomplishing this. In other words, all we have done is set up the rails. On a separate note, in general, user-experience is much better when all features/functionality is located in one place with the same branding.     ultraschuppi:  i don’t want to create an account for anything on web3. login with metamask? sure - why not. but providing sensitive information for accessing information that should be publicly available is not crypto-native   I agree. Logging in with metamask is on the TODO. Hopefully this feature will be released soon.

iammeeoh:  And what’s the point of a registration procedure?   Registration is a feature that will later be used to track progress of users, recommend tailored content, use for certifications after the completion of courses, connect users to  recruiters of the different core units, engage in community dialogue. Of course, not all of these features are present in the site at this moment.     iammeeoh:  Why don’t just give the resources directly: wiki articles, videos, whatever. This just makes it harder to navigate, longer, harder to index, etc.   I do not understand what you mean by “give the resources directly”. From your message, you imply that we do the alternative - giving resources indirectly - and I’m not sure what this means either.     iammeeoh:  What are opensource projects that have a structure like this `Maker Academy’?   I would assume most defi academies have a similar structure. Many organizations in general (whether centralized or decentralized) fall into the category that this structure adheres to - creating a market…not just serving consumers, but creating a place for producers and consumers to interact. I would also like to clarify that this diagram does not encapsulate the entire structure of Maker Academy, it just shows the content-creation side of what we do.     iammeeoh:  Why not use a combination of Wiki + StackExchange + Youtube (or others) + Khan Academy, etc without having “Maker Academy” in the middle, but rather on the side just transparently helping ‘students’ to interact with ‘experts’ ?   Please see my reply to to ultraschuppi as I think this will answer your question.

Patrick_J:  Could you elaborate on the quality control process? I’ve looked at the endgame documentation, and some fairly significant errors exist.   The quality control process is something we have struggled with. Since our existence has been somewhat unknown, and people are quite busy, we have not had as much time as we would have liked devoted to this or as many eyes as we would have liked. So far, the quality control process has been interal to the Maker Academy team. But, in the future, we plan to employ a few different measures to remedy this process:  having internal content developers speak in more generalities than specifics. Talking more about abstract principles that govern concretes, instead of the concretes themselves.  This attempts to solve the “outdated” issue. Having knowledgable users of the platform “vet” content, so average users can see what content has been “vetted” or not. But, again, quality control is tough to achieve in a silo. Hopefully, now with more eyes on the project, quality will improve.      Patrick_J:  This could potentially harm Governance as people may assume proposals have already passed and not realise there is still time for them to comment or vote.   Agreed. This should be made more clear.     Patrick_J:  Also, note it is no longer referred to as “MATH” in the proposal set.   Thank you for the clarification.

Hey Colby, thanks for your response. I see that you disagree with my prior post on amounts, but would you be willing to give more precise numbers then in line with Shuppi’s comment. If the project wasn’t allocated 600,000 DAI, does it have the ability to draw upon that much? Or how’s the set up work there.

Hi Colby, there were some good questions for @ACREinvest on discord that I hope you can address (cleaned up slightly below):  Is Colby running a separate company that produces the Academy?   Is this part of SES?   Are we voting on anything being presented here on how it’s legally and operationally set up?   What specific oversight/governance rights has Maker retained over this project and it’s sponsoring legal entity/entities (if any)?   Has DAI Foundation been involved regarding IP and permissions? Have you coordinated with the DAI Foundation to assure that appropriate IP rights are assigned there to?  I appreciate you engaging with the community, even though this did launch prematurely.

I’m not sure whether you want me to give more precise views on a future expected budget or the amount of funds that we have used already. In either case, SES is best to advise, as they control Maker Academy’s current budget/funding.     Juanbug:  If the project wasn’t allocated 600,000 DAI, does it have the ability to draw upon that much?   This question is not specific to Maker Academy, but rather the incubation program as a whole. Usually the incubation program stipulates an initial set of contributors that they are willing to support (assuming the price for each contributor is around//below market-average). And, funding for other things (software licensing, etc) is negotiated on an ad hoc basis. But, again, best for SES to describe how their incubation program works, not me. If I had to ballpark it, I would estimate that Maker Academy has used around 300,000 DAI so far. But, again, I do not look at the invoices myself, SES does. I just based this on knowing team members salaries and how long we have had each team member.

0xbocaJ:  Is Colby running a separate company that produces the Academy?   I am not running a separate company that produces the Academy.     0xbocaJ:  Is this part of SES?   Yes. Maker Academy is part of SES’s incubation program.     0xbocaJ:  Are we voting on anything being presented here on how it’s legally and operationally set up?   At some point in the future, probably (tough to say given the whole endgame proposal). But, for now, no. This is just meant to get community feedback so we can adjust the product as deemed necessary.     0xbocaJ:  What specific oversight/governance rights has Maker retained over this project and it’s sponsoring legal entity/entities (if any)?   As a part of SES (under the incubation program), I would assume the same oversight/governance rights that apply to SES. But, again, best for SES to advise.     0xbocaJ:  Has DAI Foundation been involved regarding IP and permissions? Have you coordinated with the DAI Foundation to assure that appropriate IP rights are assigned there to?   If I recall correctly, as a part of the incubation program, SES has control of Maker Academy’s IP. But, best for SES to advise.     0xbocaJ:  I appreciate you engaging with the community, even though this did launch prematurely.   Of course.

Thanks Colby! @SES-Core-Unit , could someone please confirm that we have appropriate IP assignment agreements in place? It looks like this undertaking represents a significant investment, and it would be good for the community to get some assurance that any contributors couldn’t later attempt to hold the DAO hostage via DMCA takedowns or alike.

SES has always required the aspiring core units in our incubation program to deliver open-source work, even in cases where external commercial platforms are involved. We have been the greatest advocates of this. For Maker Academy this is no different. The software as well as the content is open source and can be adopted by the Dai Foundation if it so wishes.

I’m not sure that answered my question. My concern is not whether we intend to make this open source; rather, I would like to know if we have written copyright assignment agreements with whoever actually produced these videos, text, etc, that say the copyright in these works is assigned to MakerDAO (or the Dai Foundation as appropriate). Without a written assignment, we could have an ugly copyright fight with the author down the road and find all our Maker Academy material DMCA’d. And without a written assignment, the best we could hope for is a non-exclusive license, and the creator could remonetize everything in Khan Academy, YouTube, etc. If we only have an oral or ambiguous email agreement in place, can we work to memorialize a more formal written agreement before payment is complete?
Yes. It is a standard clause in the payment agreement that all the Maker Academy contributors signed before the first invoice gets paid.
